title: (x) "Letters of the Century" book - HTF Requiem {Mark S}
content:
Hi, Just to be clear, the title of this book refers to mail not to typography.   
   
I mentioned this typophile forum to a designer friend, and he asked me to post the following. He's always wanted to know the name of this beautiful serif font. Any info is appreciated. Thank you.   
   
 ![Book type for ID](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142403im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/25060.gif)
author: alyce

comments.content:
the caps look trajan-ish...   
   
http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/trajan/regular/testdrive.html?s=LETTERS+CENTURY&p=48   
   
but not quite.

Looks like Hoefler's [Requiem](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142403/http:/www.typography.com/catalog/requiem/index.html). You can see it more clearly on [Amazon](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142403/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0385315902/ref=sib_dp_pt/102-2383946-5488922#reader-link). (That includes the italic "of the" as well.)

Thank you both for your input.   
   
Mark, Requiem it is. I had a (very) slight moment of doubt when I saw the "Y" at your link, but the character set also shows the "Y" used on the book. I'm sort of partial to that particular letter.   
   
Just curious: Is there a special name for the vertical serifs at the ends of the "T" crossbar?   
   
My friend will be pleased, and I like it too. Thank you.

Requiem has several alternate characters which can make it a little tricky to identify sometimes. The roughness of your sample image threw me at first, too.   
   
I don't think there is a special name for those vertical serifs. As far as I know they are just called vertical serifs.
